SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 1

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name Mrs. Emily R. Williams (1879-1950)

Address 1215 33rd Ave., Rex City, Mich.

Birthplace Lockport, Ill., U.S.A., 1881

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1907

Where did you set up housekeeping? Harris, Saskatchewan

Where had you been living before that? Ottawa, Ontario

For how many people did you prepare meals? 3-4 people

How far was it to your nearest store? 12 miles

How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a week

What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, tea, coffee, syrup, salt, and of course my husband and brother both used tobacco smoking. We had bought a large supply of seed, 100 quarts of fruit and preserved food. We were lucky to have meat, and luckily we were never hungry. Of course we had 2 cows and 1 doz. hens to help out in first year & I raised 125 chicks and 11 turkeys and we had 1 calf.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? White Rose, local mill

In what quantities did you buy it?

What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $7.00

How much did you use graham flour? A small amount

Whole wheat flour? None

Was flour milled locally? Yes How far away? 0.5 miles What year? 1911

What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $1.00

What other grain products did you use?

Cornmeal? Yes Whole Wheat? Yes Farina? Yes

Other? Grits, a wheat product with all of the kernel in it.

Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No

How did you grind it?

3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 25 lbs. at first and then 100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $1.00 a sack.

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use? 

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy? Sometimes 5 lbs. or 10 lbs. according to my amount of butter and eggs I had that day to go store.

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? We had 2 cows.

We used our own butter and cheese. We raised our own cows for our first milking and gotting our first 15 lbs. of oats, first butter?

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes, we packed them salted then dipping in boiling water, always standing on little end.

Did you make butter? Yes, we made butter.

Did you make cheese? Yes, we made cheese.

What kind of cheese? Whole milk or called full cream cheese.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? We took in 2 hatched and cured pigs first year and got a 2 mo. old pig kept it all summer and brought it in fall.

How did you get fresh meat? We shot wild grouse, ducks, geese, rabbits quite often lots spring & fall.

How did you preserve meat? We salted them and put down other parts in lard and froze our beef in winter.

How often did you get fresh meat?

How did you preserve meat?

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Yes.

If so what year was it organized? Not sure.

Did you use game? Yes, plenty.

What kinds? Grouse, rabbits, Geese and ducks, and some deer by going 50 Mi. north to Sask. River.

For how long? As long as we lived there with a license of course.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not so very much.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Mostly canned or frozen.

Kinds? Salmon and codfish and smelt.

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying? 
Peas? 
Corn? 
Littles beans? 
Saskatoons? 
Other foods? 

That year did you first preserve fruit by canning? 
1907 
1912 we began to ship in fruit from B.C. by rail. Apples by box. 
That year did you first preserve vegetables by canning? 
1918 

That year did you first preserve meat by canning? 
1926 

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying? 
I can and freeze as I have refrigerator and freezer.

To what extent? I raise and can all kinds of fruits here since I live in Rich. In town on a 50 c. lot. Farmer will crop out. 
Did you make your own wine? 
I did try but it never proved very satisfactory as it never was strong enough.

10. BAKING

What type of yeast did you use? Compressed dry yeast.

Did you make yeast for your own use? Yes, I buy using starter? No, first year I used a starter with hops.

Using hops? Yes. Salt rising? No. We did use a lump of dough from one baking to the other, only in winter.

Did you buy baking powder? Yes. Baking soda? Yes.

Cream of tartar? Yes. Did you make your own baking powder? No.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) Slough; till we dug a well in summer of 1907, 12 ft.

How far was this water from your home? 1/2 mile.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

We drew water from a well over a pully, then we moved to 26, 33, 12. In 1911 we dug a shallow well, 12 ft. deep and had a pump and used well as a cooler as well. Then in 1912 we dug a deep well, 12 ft. deep well 30 ft. In 1916 put up a windmill and a big tank and had a heater for winter to keep it from freezing up.

To draw water from a well over a pull, when we moved to 26, 32, 12, in 1911 and dug a shallow well, 12 ft., when we moved to 26, 32, 12, in 1911 and dug a deep well, 12 ft., deep well 12 ft., Winter 1910 put up a windmill and had a hooper for winter to keep it from freezing up.

What kinds of laundry soap did the grocer handle?

Where did you get your fuel? 

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

Once in 1916 we tried a straw burner for heat. It was perfect heat but everything smelled so of straw, we had to discard it.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

First, most things came in wooden boxes and in bulk; by 1918-1919 we began to get things in paper and cardboard wrappings at present most in cellophane.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

We were well fed as I always aimed to have a balanced ration. Breakfast: Bread, butter, meat or eggs, potatoes, fruit and cookies, tea or coffee and always jam or jelly.

Dinner: Meat, potatoes, vegetable, bread, butter, jam, pie or pudding tea or coffee.

Supper: Bread, butter, jam, meat, potatoes, vegetable, fruit or cookies. Not much change the year round. There were three of us. First my Bro. was with us the first year and till Oct. 1928 when we were 2 of us till 1935 we had a man the year round.

My husband was 28 yrs. and I was 26 yrs. and so on up.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Canada?

........1917........ Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

We had a turkey dinner and all the fixings. Turkey, dressing, gravy, baked beans, cabbage salad, carrots, turnips, cake pickles, canned tomatoes, steamed pudding, apple pie, fruit cake, bread, rolls, jam, butter, canned peaches, tea, candy, nuts, fresh apples (northern spy). We invited Mr. and Mrs. Simpson and their family of three children for dinner. Their ages were, Mr. S was 37 yrs. Mrs. S was 26 yrs. Oldest child, a girl 6, next a boy 4, and smaller boy nearly three.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details. No we always had plenty of food.

We took in a year's supply of food and I always gathered all the wild fruit I could get and raised all the garden stuff that would grow in that climate. We worked on a steam thrashing outfit the first year, to get our year's supply of food and made a trip to Saskatoon in a schooner wagon to get it. We even slept in the wagon while there, to save money to have a nice Xmas.
17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest settlers in the area at that time.

18. What food did you serve your first Christmas dinner in western Kansas?

19. Were you ever forced to live at a station level living on one or two acres? How did you produce food? In detail. Did we always have plenty of food? We took in a year's supply of food and I always gathered all the wild fruit I could get and raised all the garden stuff that would grow in that climate. We worked on a storm porch and made a trip to the first year to get our year's supply of food and even slept in an old schoolhouse to save money to buy a new house.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

With me there was much difference in preparing meals, as I worked out in the field with my husband and had to bake bread and so forth at night. Set better the night before and rise at midnight and coffee, put in pans in morning first thing at 5 o'clock. Back in those days I went to town only took off one day a week to wash, iron, churn and other things needing attention. Always raised around 350 chickens and had them to feed. Raised from 10 to 70 turkeys, according to the luck I had. I always prepared my meals from the beginning.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homemade and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and tales as possible).

We never lived on prepared foods. Always raised our own and bought fruit began. We learned later from 1912 to send to B.C. orchards for fruit.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Eastern Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of purchasing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed). Under the sod house in dug basement we left our potatoes in 1909 & 1910 when we went home to Kansas and only covered them with paper and blankets and only lost a bu. or two, around the edge where we were careless in covering them. In 1908 when we bought our pig to raise from, she used to get out and she dug all of our potatoes that year. We had to go out and dig potatoes on shares to get ours that year. Potatoes were small that year and we could have sold them all that fall. I was afraid and we had to peel marbles all winter. Next spring the store got in some nice sized ones for $1.00 a bu. After that experience we always raised enough potatoes for our own use. Used garden truck and sold to the Hotel and stores. I never felt we could pay for eats out of our crop. I always sold butter and eggs an cheese and garden crop to meet such costs. I even paid for my piano in later years by raising turkeys, also for my own false teeth by raising turkeys. Quite a few people made ice-wells, in the ground for storage. They dug a hole and adjoing leading down and flooded it in winter, in zero weather and got sandust to cover it with. We had our shallow well, and was such a good cooler, we never fixed a well.
22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and comparing them in other towns, including prices, quality, methods of payment, etc.

In conclusion, I would like to express my gratitude to all who have supported me throughout this journey. Your kindness and encouragement have been invaluable.

Thank you for your time and attention.

Sincerely,
